text: In a newly formed data integration in healthcare where meeting start times slip and multiple workstreams overlap, what should the project manager do to establish an environment that fosters adherence to ground rules?

options.label: facilitate the team in co-authoring ground rules and model them
impose rules unilaterally without team input
ignore when leaders break the rules
set rules once and never revisit them

explanation: Option a is correct because co-creation and modeling encourage adherence. Option b is incorrect because top-down rules reduce ownership and adherence. Option c is incorrect because inconsistent enforcement undermines norms. Option d is incorrect because stale rules stop fitting the team environment.

text: Given a matrixed analytics platform in edtech where some members dominate discussions and several new hires just joined, which action best helps establish an environment that fosters adherence to ground rules?

options.label: punish minor slips publicly
make the rules visible and tie reminders to ceremonies
bury the rules in a document no one reads
impose rules unilaterally without team input

explanation: Option b is correct because visibility and repetition reinforce norms. Option a is incorrect because public punishment harms safety and adherence. Option c is incorrect because invisible norms are hard to follow. Option d is incorrect because top-down rules reduce ownership and adherence.

text: While a hybrid mobile app in public sector where some members dominate discussions and vendors are joining the team, what is the most effective next step to establish an environment that fosters adherence to ground rules?

options.label: ignore when leaders break the rules
set rules once and never revisit them
recognize and reward behaviors that follow the rules
punish minor slips publicly

explanation: Option c is correct because positive reinforcement builds the desired environment. Option a is incorrect because inconsistent enforcement undermines norms. Option b is incorrect because stale rules stop fitting the team environment. Option d is incorrect because public punishment harms safety and adherence.

text: Facing a cross-functional data integration in healthcare where chat channels are noisy and unstructured and multiple workstreams overlap, what should the project manager do first to establish an environment that fosters adherence to ground rules?

options.label: bury the rules in a document no one reads
impose rules unilaterally without team input
ignore when leaders break the rules
ensure psychological safety so concerns about norms can be raised

explanation: Option d is correct because people follow norms when they can speak up safely. Option a is incorrect because invisible norms are hard to follow. Option b is incorrect because top-down rules reduce ownership and adherence. Option c is incorrect because inconsistent enforcement undermines norms.

text: In a agile analytics platform in fintech where chat channels are noisy and unstructured and key milestones are approaching, what should the project manager do to establish an environment that fosters adherence to ground rules?

options.label: periodically revisit the rules to keep them relevant
set rules once and never revisit them
punish minor slips publicly
bury the rules in a document no one reads

explanation: Option a is correct because updating norms maintains commitment. Option b is incorrect because stale rules stop fitting the team environment. Option c is incorrect because public punishment harms safety and adherence. Option d is incorrect because invisible norms are hard to follow.
